etymologies: Old English alewe, alwe (denoting the fragrant resin or heartwood of certain oriental trees), via Latin from Greek aloē; reinforced in late Middle English by Old French aloes ‘aloe’, hence frequently used in the plural

definitions: a succulent plant, typically having a rosette of toothed fleshy leaves and bell-shaped or tubular flowers on long stems. Native to the Old World tropics, several species are cultivated commercially or as ornamentals.
shortDefinitions: succulent plant with rosette of thick tapering leaves and bell-shaped or tubular flowers on long stems

definitions: a strong laxative obtained from the bitter juice of various kinds of aloe.
shortDefinitions: strong laxative obtained from bitter juice of various kinds of aloe

definitions: the fragrant heartwood of a tropical Asian tree.

notes.text: The wood is obtained from two trees of the genus Aquilaria, family Thymelaeaceae, especially A. agallocha

shortDefinitions: fragrant heartwood of tropical Asian tree

definitions: the resin obtained from aloeswood, used in perfume, incense, and medicine.
shortDefinitions: resin obtained from aloes wood, used in perfume and medicine
